newsitem.title: UK: UK job centres offer mainly low pay work - survey.
newsitem.headline: UK job centres offer mainly low pay work - survey.

text.p: Vacancies at British job centres are mainly for poorly paid work with some paying less than one pound an hour, a new survey by the Trades Union Congress shows.
The report showed almost half the vacancies surveyed paid less than 3.70 stg ($6.19) an hour, with the lowest rate at 74p an hour for a nanny.
More than 5,000 jobs surveyed in England and Wales paid an average weekly wage of 168.90 stg for a full-time job, almost half the national average.
Nearly a third paid less than 61 pounds a week and one in three vacancies were part-time, according to the survey by the TUC Unemployed Centres.
On top of that, one in 10 jobs on offer were for more than 48 hours a week, in contravention of European Union rules on maximum working hours.

TUC general secretary John Monks said: "The survey shows that the jobs on offer are likely to be low paid and part-time. Many of the full-time jobs pay so little that people will have to do excessive hours just to receive a living wage."

Doug Low of the TUC unemployed centres network said that from this week, under the new Jobseeker's Allowance which replaced old-style unemployment benefit in October, people will no longer be able to refuse a job on the grounds that it pays too little.
"The government's plan of transferring people from out-of-work poverty to in-work poverty has been exposed," he said.
The Office for National Statistics will release official unemployment statistics for December at 0930 GMT on Wednesday.
A Reuter poll of economists found a consensus forecast that Britain's jobless queues were reduced by 30,000 last month, following a record drop of 96,000 the month before.
